claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling, initiating downstream antitumor immunity.

evidence.quote: 1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
2. Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.

claims.caveat: Evidence is based on preclinical murine models and may not fully translate to humans.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination broadens the tumor immunopeptidome, increasing the fraction of tumor proteins presented on MHC molecules.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape

claims.caveat: The magnitude of expansion is measured in murine tumors and may differ in human cancers.

claims.claim: PD‑L1 expression in tumor tissue increases after mRNA vaccination, enhancing the targetability of checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: PD‑L1 up‑regulation may reflect an adaptive resistance mechanism rather than a purely beneficial effect.

claims.claim: Combining intratumoral mRNA vaccination with anti‑PD‑L1 therapy improves tumor control in mice and is associated with improved survival in a retrospective human cohort.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: Human evidence is retrospective, non‑randomized, and subject to confounding factors.
